articles.headline: The War Killed Her Dreams. To Survive, She Treated Its Fighters.
articles.snippet: Trapped in Sudan’s brutal civil war, a young woman chose to work in a clinic on the front line, treating civilians and combatants. She had to navigate suspicion from both sides.
articles.abstract: Trapped in Sudan’s brutal civil war, a young woman chose to work in a clinic on the front line, treating civilians and combatants. She had to navigate suspicion from both sides.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a makeshift clinic in Sudan’s battle-torn capital, a determined young woman rushed to save fighters and civilians alike.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Ivor Prickett

articles.headline: Why Taiwan’s Foxconn, an iPhone Supplier, Is Investing in Texas and Thailand
articles.snippet: The Apple supplier has spent millions in the United States, India and Mexico over the past two years to lessen its dependence on China.
articles.abstract: The Apple supplier has spent millions in the United States, India and Mexico over the past two years to lessen its dependence on China.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, the giant Taiwanese electronics manufacturer Foxconn spent $33 million to buy a 10-acre tract of land north of Houston to expand its operations. It is also building factories in India and Mexico and investing hundreds of millions of dollars in Thailand.
articles.byline: By Meaghan Tobin and John Liu

articles.headline: How Mexican Cartels Test Fentanyl on Vulnerable People and Animals
articles.snippet: A global crackdown on fentanyl has led cartels to innovate production methods and test their risky formulas on people, as well as rabbits and chickens.
articles.abstract: A global crackdown on fentanyl has led cartels to innovate production methods and test their risky formulas on people, as well as rabbits and chickens.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cartel operatives came to the homeless encampment carrying syringes filled with their latest fentanyl formula. The offer was simple, according to two men living at the camp in northwest Mexico: up to $30 for anyone willing to inject themselves with the concoction.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff, Paulina Villegas and Meridith Kohut

articles.headline: How A.I. Could Reshape the Economic Geography of America
articles.snippet: As the technology is widely adopted, some once-struggling midsize cities in the Midwest, Mid-Atlantic and South may benefit, new research predicts.
articles.abstract: As the technology is widely adopted, some once-struggling midsize cities in the Midwest, Mid-Atlantic and South may benefit, new research predicts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chattanooga, Tenn., a midsize Southern city, is on no one’s list of artificial intelligence hot spots.

articles.headline: Israel Loosened Its Rules to Bomb Hamas Fighters, Killing Many More Civilians
articles.snippet: Surprised by Oct. 7 and fearful of another attack, Israel weakened safeguards meant to protect noncombatants, allowing officers to endanger up to 20 people in each airstrike. One of the deadliest bombardments of the 21st century followed.
articles.abstract: Surprised by Oct. 7 and fearful of another attack, Israel weakened safeguards meant to protect noncombatants, allowing officers to endanger up to 20 people in each airstrike. One of the deadliest bombardments of the 21st century followed.
articles.lead_paragraph: At exactly 1 p.m. on Oct. 7, 2023, Israel’s military leadership issued an order that unleashed one of the most intense bombing campaigns in contemporary warfare.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley, Natan Odenheimer, Bilal Shbair, Ronen Bergman, John Ismay, Sheera Frenkel and Adam Sella

articles.headline: Plane Crash Investigators Focus on Russian Air Defenses as Possible Cause
articles.snippet: Russian aviation authorities said the Azerbaijan Airlines plane had hit a flock of birds. But some experts cast doubt on that account, pointing to footage showing apparent holes in the fuselage.
articles.abstract: Russian aviation authorities said the Azerbaijan Airlines plane had hit a flock of birds. But some experts cast doubt on that account, pointing to footage showing apparent holes in the fuselage.
articles.lead_paragraph: As authorities in several countries tried to determine what caused the deadly crash of a passenger airplane in Kazakhstan, investigators and experts on Thursday were focusing on the possibility that a Russian air defense system had struck the plane.

articles.headline: Worried About Market Turmoil Under Trump? Look to the Past.
articles.snippet: Readers have concerns that President-elect Trump’s policy agenda will unsettle stocks. If you’re tempted to make big portfolio moves, revisit 2020.
articles.abstract: Readers have concerns that President-elect Trump’s policy agenda will unsettle stocks. If you’re tempted to make big portfolio moves, revisit 2020.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nobody knows what will send the stock market into a tailspin, or when that moment may be coming. This is the inherent risk that comes with investing.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber
